graph.original_query: You are the Orchestrator Agent.Your first action is to call SIPGoalPlannerAgent to compute goal inputs, inflation adjustment, SIP math, allocation guidance, and projections.Do not build any plans until you have read SIPGoalPlannerAgent’s outputs.Wiring RequirementPlannerAgent MUST first read the outputs from SIPGoalPlannerAgent (especially goal_input_json and computed parameters) before creating the final multi-agent plan graph for retrieval, distillation, Q&A, charts, and report.- Prepare JSON outputs for projection line, allocation doughnut using CoderAgent using different input and derived parameters- Prepare data for first 12 rows for sip_projection_table_json  using CoderAgent using different input and derived parametersUser ScenarioPlan a SIP goal with asset allocation and fund category guidance:goal_type = Retirementcurrent_age = 50retirement_age = 60override_time_horizon_years = 10currency = INRtarget_amount_min = 30000000risk_appetite = highCompute (Deterministic)time_horizon_years = max(override_time_horizon_years, retirement_age - current_age) = max(10, 60 - 50) = 10total_months = time_horizon_years * 12 = 120Risk → Return mapping (annual):very_low: 5%low: 7%low_moderate: 8%moderate: 10%high_moderate: 11%high: 12%very_high: 14%monthly_return_r = annual_return / 12For this scenario (high): annual_return = 12% → monthly_return_r = 0.12 / 12 = 0.01Inflation default: 5.5% annually unless overridden.Do (Step-by-Step)Normalize inputs → emit goal_input_json.Refer “SIP Calculation” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Refer “Inflation Adjustment” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Refer “Recommendation Engine (Fund Category Types)” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Output allocation_plan_json (equity %, debt %, recommended categories, notes).Guideline risk for appetite:"guideline": {"very_low": "Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity","low": "Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity","low_moderate": "Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity","moderate": "Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt","high_moderate": "High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt","high": "High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt","very_high": "Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt"}Validation Hooks: Validate schema + percentages.Visualization (ReportGeneratorAgent):Pie chart → equity vs debtBar/graph → sub-categoriesStrictness: Never recommend fund names. Only fund categories.Schemasgoal_input_json{ "goal_type": string, "target_amount": number, "currency": "INR", "time_horizon_years": number, "total_months": number, "risk_appetite": string }inflation_adjusted_json{ "inflation_pct": number, "years": number, "unadjusted_target": number, "adjusted_target": number }sip_calc_json{ "monthly_return_r": number, "months_n": number, "adjusted_target": number, "monthly_sip": number, "status": "ok" | "error", "error": string | null }allocation_plan_json{"equity_percent": number,"debt_percent": number,"recommended_fund_categories": {"equity": string[],"debt": string[],"elss_optional": boolean},"notes": {"very_low": string,"low": string,"low_moderate": string,"moderate": string,"high_moderate": string,"high": string,"very_high": string}}Outputs RequiredEmit STRICT JSON (no prose, no markdown):goal_input_jsoninflation_adjusted_jsonsip_calc_jsonallocation_plan_json====================================================================Addendum – Mandatory Report Sections for SIP Reports====================================================================All orchestrations and plan graphs must ensure downstream agents(FormatterAgent, ReportGeneratorAgent, QAAgent) enforce the followingsections in the final comprehensive_report.html:1. Executive Summary2. Goal Inputs3. Inflation Adjustment4. SIP Calculation5. Asset Allocation Plan6. Allocation Notes7. Key Recommendations8. Risk Factors and Uncertainties (≥150 words)9. SIP Charts (Projection line + Allocation doughnut)10. SIP Projection (long-horizon summary)11. 12 month sip projection table- PlannerAgent must wire in chart_data_json (T015) and first_12_months_table_json (T016).- ReportGeneratorAgent must embed these sections in HTML.- QAAgent must validate that all sections are present and populated.====================================================================

T001.initial_thoughts: Okay, I will collect the inputs, compute the SIP amount with inflation adjustment, map the asset allocation based on the risk profile, and prepare the JSON outputs for downstream agents. I will use the provided formulas and risk appetite mappings.

notes.very_low: Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity
notes.low: Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity
notes.low_moderate: Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity
notes.moderate: Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt
notes.high_moderate: High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt
notes.high: High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt
notes.very_high: Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt

ALL CALCULATORS Explore Calculators Goal SIP Calculator Top-up SIP Calculator Impact of Inflation Calculator Liquid Fund Calculator Emergency Fund Calculator SIP Calculator Lumpsum Calculator INSIGHTS Domestic Insights CEO Letters ALL INSIGHTS Reducing Retirement corpus anxieties The PGIM India Retirement Readiness Survey 2023 revealed some interesting insights that I thought would be helpful for people to know who are considering building their retirement corpus. The surprising truth behind wealth creation Everyone dreams of high investment returns doubling money overnight, finding the next big stock or riding a crypto wave to riches. What is sequence of return risk Imagine your cricket team is chasing a big target and loses 5 wickets early. Even if the middle order plays well, the team is under pressure. Time-tested strategy to tackle volatile markets Eddy Elfenbein is a Washington DC-based portfolio manager and editor of the blog Crossing Wall Street. final_report.detailed:
Let me think through this: The fund shortlist from T012 provides potential funds for investment, while T001 outlines the overall asset allocation strategy based on a 'high' risk appetite (70% equity, 30% debt) and provides recommended fund categories.  The goal is to ensure that the recommended funds align with this strategy.

**Equity Allocation (70%):**

The recommended equity categories from T001 are Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap. The fund shortlist from T012 contains several Mid Cap funds and general 'Equity' funds. The Mid Cap funds directly align with the Mid Cap category. However, the general 'Equity' funds require further scrutiny to ensure they align with either Large Cap or Small Cap categories.  The 'PGIM India' funds are broadly categorized as Equity.  To ensure diversification, it is important to allocate portions to Large Cap and Small Cap funds as well. The absence of explicit Large Cap and Small Cap funds in the initial shortlist is a limitation. These could be added in a future selection round.

*   **Recommended Mid Cap Funds:**
    *   Quant Mid Cap Fund
    *   Motilal Oswal Midcap Fund - Regular Plan
    *   Nippon India Growth Fund
    *   HDFC Mid-Cap Opportunities Fund
    *   SBI Magnum Midcap Fund
*   **Recommended Equity Funds (requires further classification):**
    *   PGIM India Flexi Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Midcap Fund
    *   PGIM India Large and Mid Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Large Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India ELSS Tax Saver Fund
    *   PGIM India Small Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Retirement Fund
    *   PGIM India Multi Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Healthcare Fund

**Debt Allocation (30%):**

The recommended debt categories from T001 are Short Term Debt and Corporate Bond.  The fund shortlist does not contain any specific debt funds. Therefore, the debt allocation needs to be addressed by selecting appropriate Short Term Debt and Corporate Bond funds. This constitutes a gap in the current shortlist.

**Allocation Plan:**

The allocation plan should aim to distribute the 70% equity portion across Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap, and the 30% debt portion across Short Term Debt and Corporate Bond funds. A possible distribution could be:

*   Large Cap: 20%
*   Mid Cap: 25%
*   Small Cap: 25%
*   Short Term Debt: 15%
*   Corporate Bond: 15%

This is just an example, and the exact percentages should be adjusted based on the specific characteristics and risk profiles of the selected funds.

**Risks and Warnings:**

*   The fund shortlist is incomplete, particularly for debt funds.  The recommended allocation cannot be fully implemented with the current shortlist.
*   The 'Equity' funds in T012 need further classification to ensure they align with the desired asset allocation. Not all 'Equity' funds are created equal, and some might be sector-specific or have a higher risk profile than others.
*   The indicative ratings in T012 are not consistently available for all funds. This limits the ability to assess the quality and performance of the funds. The 'processing_status' and 'quality_assessment' in T012 highlight the partial nature of the extracted data, requiring caution in decision-making.

**Recommendations:**

1.  **Expand the Fund Shortlist:** Add more funds to the shortlist, specifically focusing on Large Cap, Small Cap, Short Term Debt, and Corporate Bond funds.
2.  **Classify Equity Funds:**  Thoroughly evaluate the 'Equity' funds in the shortlist to determine their suitability for the Large Cap and Small Cap categories.
3.  **Consider Indicative Ratings:**  Prioritize funds with higher indicative ratings (where available) to improve the overall quality of the portfolio.
4.  **Diversify Across Fund Managers:** While PGIM funds are prominent in the list, ensure diversification by including funds from other reputable fund managers.
5.  **Consult with a Financial Advisor:**  The allocation plan should be reviewed and adjusted by a qualified financial advisor to ensure it aligns with the investor's specific financial goals and risk tolerance.

output.formatted_report_T017:
📊 COMPREHENSIVE SIP ANALYSIS REPORT

🎯 Executive Summary

This report provides a comprehensive analysis of a Systematic Investment Plan (SIP) designed to achieve a retirement goal of ₹30,000,000 in 10 years, adjusted for inflation. The analysis includes goal inputs, inflation adjustments, SIP calculations, asset allocation plans, and risk factors. A high-risk appetite suggests a 70% equity and 30% debt allocation. The fund shortlist is currently missing debt fund recommendations, representing a key area for revision. Despite this limitation, the report outlines potential equity fund allocations based on available data and provides recommendations for expanding the fund selection to achieve full diversification.

🎯 Goal Inputs

Goal Type: Retirement
Target Amount: ₹30,000,000
Time Horizon: 10 years (120 months)
Risk Appetite: High

💰 Inflation Adjustment

Inflation Rate: 5.5%
Unadjusted Target: ₹30,000,000
Adjusted Target: ₹51,264,538.96

🧮 SIP Calculation

Monthly Return (r): 0.01
Number of Months (n): 120
Adjusted Target: ₹51,264,538.96
Monthly SIP Amount: ₹251,578.44

📈 Asset Allocation Plan

Equity Allocation: 70%
Debt Allocation: 30%

Recommended Fund Categories:

  • Equity: Large Cap, Mid Cap, Small Cap
  • Debt: Short Term Debt, Corporate Bond
  • ELSS (Optional): Yes

📝 Allocation Notes

Risk Appetite Guidelines:

  • Very Low: Extremely conservative (90% debt / 10% equity)
  • Low: Conservative (70% debt / 30% equity)
  • Low-Moderate: Tilted conservative (60% debt / 40% equity)
  • Moderate: Balanced mix (50% equity / 50% debt)
  • High-Moderate: Tilted aggressive (60% equity / 40% debt)
  • High: Aggressive (70% equity / 30% debt)
  • Very High: Extremely aggressive (90% equity / 10% debt)

🔑 Key Recommendations

  1. Expand the fund shortlist to include Large Cap, Small Cap, Short Term Debt, and Corporate Bond funds.
  2. Classify existing 'Equity' funds into Large Cap and Small Cap categories.
  3. Consider indicative ratings when available to prioritize higher-quality funds.
  4. Diversify across fund managers to reduce concentration risk.
  5. Consult a financial advisor for personalized advice.

⚠️ Risk Factors and Uncertainties

Investing in financial markets involves inherent risks that can impact the achievement of financial goals. Understanding and mitigating these risks is crucial for effective financial planning. Several risk factors and uncertainties could affect the outcome of the SIP plan:

  • Market Volatility: Equity markets are subject to volatility, influenced by economic conditions, geopolitical events, and investor sentiment. Unexpected market downturns can reduce portfolio value and impact returns.
  • Inflation Risk: The inflation rate could exceed the assumed 5.5%, eroding the real value of returns. If inflation rises significantly, the target corpus may not be sufficient to maintain purchasing power.
  • Interest Rate Risk: Changes in interest rates can affect the performance of debt funds. Rising interest rates may decrease the value of existing bond holdings.
  • Credit Risk: Corporate bond funds carry credit risk, which is the possibility that the issuer may default on its debt obligations.
  • Liquidity Risk: Certain investments may be difficult to sell quickly without incurring losses, posing a liquidity risk.
  • Fund Manager Risk: The performance of the selected funds depends on the skill and expertise of the fund managers. Poor fund management can lead to underperformance.
  • Regulatory and Policy Changes: Changes in government regulations and policies can impact the investment landscape.
  • Incomplete Fund Shortlist: The current fund shortlist is missing debt fund recommendations, limiting the ability to fully implement the asset allocation strategy.
  • Equity Fund Classification: Existing equity funds need further classification to ensure alignment with the desired asset allocation, and some might be sector-specific or have a higher risk profile.
  • Indicative Rating Availability: Indicative ratings are not consistently available, limiting the ability to fully assess fund quality.
  • Concentration Risk: Relying solely on the PGIM fund family introduces concentration risk and diversification is key.

These risks highlight the importance of continuous monitoring, diversification, and professional financial advice to navigate market uncertainties and optimize investment outcomes. A financial advisor should be consulted for personalized financial guidance.

risk_appetite = high

Compute (Deterministic)
time_horizon_years = max(override_time_horizon_years, retirement_age - current_age) = max(10, 60 - 50) = 10
total_months = time_horizon_years * 12 = 120

Risk → Return mapping (annual):
very_low: 5%
low: 7%
low_moderate: 8%
moderate: 10%
high_moderate: 11%
high: 12%
very_high: 14%
monthly_return_r = annual_return / 12
For this scenario (high): annual_return = 12% → monthly_return_r = 0.12 / 12 = 0.01
Inflation default: 5.5% annually unless overridden.

Do (Step-by-Step)
Normalize inputs → emit goal_input_json.
Refer “SIP Calculation” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.
Refer “Inflation Adjustment” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.
Refer “Recommendation Engine (Fund Category Types)” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.
Output allocation_plan_json (equity %, debt %, recommended categories, notes).
Guideline risk for appetite:
"guideline": {"very_low": "Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity","low": "Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity","low_moderate": "Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity","moderate": "Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt","high_moderate": "High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt","high": "High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt","very_high": "Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt"}

Validation Hooks: Validate schema + percentages.
Strictness: Never recommend fund names. Only fund categories.

Outputs Required
Emit STRICT JSON (no prose, no markdown):
goal_input_json
inflation_adjusted_json
sip_calc_json
allocation_plan_json

output.initial_thoughts: Okay, I will collect the inputs, compute the SIP amount with inflation adjustment, map the asset allocation based on the risk profile, and prepare the JSON outputs for downstream agents. I will use the provided formulas and risk appetite mappings.

notes.very_low: Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity
notes.low: Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity
notes.low_moderate: Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity
notes.moderate: Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt
notes.high_moderate: High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt
notes.high: High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt
notes.very_high: Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt

nodes.description: Fetch raw fund data based on T001 allocation categories and risk.
nodes.agent_prompt: Fetch raw fund data based on the allocation_plan_json.recommended_fund_categories from T001.output and the risk_appetite 'high' from the initial query. Do NOT recommend fund names, only fund categories.

final_report.detailed:
Let me think through this: The fund shortlist from T012 provides potential funds for investment, while T001 outlines the overall asset allocation strategy based on a 'high' risk appetite (70% equity, 30% debt) and provides recommended fund categories.  The goal is to ensure that the recommended funds align with this strategy.

**Equity Allocation (70%):**

The recommended equity categories from T001 are Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap. The fund shortlist from T012 contains several Mid Cap funds and general 'Equity' funds. The Mid Cap funds directly align with the Mid Cap category. However, the general 'Equity' funds require further scrutiny to ensure they align with either Large Cap or Small Cap categories.  The 'PGIM India' funds are broadly categorized as Equity.  To ensure diversification, it is important to allocate portions to Large Cap and Small Cap funds as well. The absence of explicit Large Cap and Small Cap funds in the initial shortlist is a limitation. These could be added in a future selection round.

*   **Recommended Mid Cap Funds:**
    *   Quant Mid Cap Fund
    *   Motilal Oswal Midcap Fund - Regular Plan
    *   Nippon India Growth Fund
    *   HDFC Mid-Cap Opportunities Fund
    *   SBI Magnum Midcap Fund
*   **Recommended Equity Funds (requires further classification):**
    *   PGIM India Flexi Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Midcap Fund
    *   PGIM India Large and Mid Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Large Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India ELSS Tax Saver Fund
    *   PGIM India Small Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Retirement Fund
    *   PGIM India Multi Cap Fund
    *   PGIM India Healthcare Fund

**Debt Allocation (30%):**

The recommended debt categories from T001 are Short Term Debt and Corporate Bond.  The fund shortlist does not contain any specific debt funds. Therefore, the debt allocation needs to be addressed by selecting appropriate Short Term Debt and Corporate Bond funds. This constitutes a gap in the current shortlist.

**Allocation Plan:**

The allocation plan should aim to distribute the 70% equity portion across Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap, and the 30% debt portion across Short Term Debt and Corporate Bond funds. A possible distribution could be:

*   Large Cap: 20%
*   Mid Cap: 25%
*   Small Cap: 25%
*   Short Term Debt: 15%
*   Corporate Bond: 15%

This is just an example, and the exact percentages should be adjusted based on the specific characteristics and risk profiles of the selected funds.

**Risks and Warnings:**

*   The fund shortlist is incomplete, particularly for debt funds.  The recommended allocation cannot be fully implemented with the current shortlist.
*   The 'Equity' funds in T012 need further classification to ensure they align with the desired asset allocation. Not all 'Equity' funds are created equal, and some might be sector-specific or have a higher risk profile than others.
*   The indicative ratings in T012 are not consistently available for all funds. This limits the ability to assess the quality and performance of the funds. The 'processing_status' and 'quality_assessment' in T012 highlight the partial nature of the extracted data, requiring caution in decision-making.

**Recommendations:**

1.  **Expand the Fund Shortlist:** Add more funds to the shortlist, specifically focusing on Large Cap, Small Cap, Short Term Debt, and Corporate Bond funds.
2.  **Classify Equity Funds:**  Thoroughly evaluate the 'Equity' funds in the shortlist to determine their suitability for the Large Cap and Small Cap categories.
3.  **Consider Indicative Ratings:**  Prioritize funds with higher indicative ratings (where available) to improve the overall quality of the portfolio.
4.  **Diversify Across Fund Managers:** While PGIM funds are prominent in the list, ensure diversification by including funds from other reputable fund managers.
5.  **Consult with a Financial Advisor:**  The allocation plan should be reviewed and adjusted by a qualified financial advisor to ensure it aligns with the investor's specific financial goals and risk tolerance.
recommendations: Expand the fund shortlist to include Large Cap, Small Cap, Short Term Debt, and Corporate Bond funds.

output.formatted_report_T017:
📊 COMPREHENSIVE SIP ANALYSIS REPORT

🎯 Executive Summary

This report provides a comprehensive analysis of a Systematic Investment Plan (SIP) designed to achieve a retirement goal of ₹30,000,000 in 10 years, adjusted for inflation. The analysis includes goal inputs, inflation adjustments, SIP calculations, asset allocation plans, and risk factors. A high-risk appetite suggests a 70% equity and 30% debt allocation. The fund shortlist is currently missing debt fund recommendations, representing a key area for revision. Despite this limitation, the report outlines potential equity fund allocations based on available data and provides recommendations for expanding the fund selection to achieve full diversification.

🎯 Goal Inputs

Goal Type: Retirement
Target Amount: ₹30,000,000
Time Horizon: 10 years (120 months)
Risk Appetite: High

💰 Inflation Adjustment

Inflation Rate: 5.5%
Unadjusted Target: ₹30,000,000
Adjusted Target: ₹51,264,538.96

🧮 SIP Calculation

Monthly Return (r): 0.01
Number of Months (n): 120
Adjusted Target: ₹51,264,538.96
Monthly SIP Amount: ₹251,578.44

📈 Asset Allocation Plan

Equity Allocation: 70%
Debt Allocation: 30%

Recommended Fund Categories:

  • Equity: Large Cap, Mid Cap, Small Cap
  • Debt: Short Term Debt, Corporate Bond
  • ELSS (Optional): Yes

📝 Allocation Notes

Risk Appetite Guidelines:

  • Very Low: Extremely conservative (90% debt / 10% equity)
  • Low: Conservative (70% debt / 30% equity)
  • Low-Moderate: Tilted conservative (60% debt / 40% equity)
  • Moderate: Balanced mix (50% equity / 50% debt)
  • High-Moderate: Tilted aggressive (60% equity / 40% debt)
  • High: Aggressive (70% equity / 30% debt)
  • Very High: Extremely aggressive (90% equity / 10% debt)

🔑 Key Recommendations

  1. Expand the fund shortlist to include Large Cap, Small Cap, Short Term Debt, and Corporate Bond funds.
  2. Classify existing 'Equity' funds into Large Cap and Small Cap categories.
  3. Consider indicative ratings when available to prioritize higher-quality funds.
  4. Diversify across fund managers to reduce concentration risk.
  5. Consult a financial advisor for personalized advice.

⚠️ Risk Factors and Uncertainties

Investing in financial markets involves inherent risks that can impact the achievement of financial goals. Understanding and mitigating these risks is crucial for effective financial planning. Several risk factors and uncertainties could affect the outcome of the SIP plan:

  • Market Volatility: Equity markets are subject to volatility, influenced by economic conditions, geopolitical events, and investor sentiment. Unexpected market downturns can reduce portfolio value and impact returns.
  • Inflation Risk: The inflation rate could exceed the assumed 5.5%, eroding the real value of returns. If inflation rises significantly, the target corpus may not be sufficient to maintain purchasing power.
  • Interest Rate Risk: Changes in interest rates can affect the performance of debt funds. Rising interest rates may decrease the value of existing bond holdings.
  • Credit Risk: Corporate bond funds carry credit risk, which is the possibility that the issuer may default on its debt obligations.
  • Liquidity Risk: Certain investments may be difficult to sell quickly without incurring losses, posing a liquidity risk.
  • Fund Manager Risk: The performance of the selected funds depends on the skill and expertise of the fund managers. Poor fund management can lead to underperformance.
  • Regulatory and Policy Changes: Changes in government regulations and policies can impact the investment landscape.
  • Incomplete Fund Shortlist: The current fund shortlist is missing debt fund recommendations, limiting the ability to fully implement the asset allocation strategy.
  • Equity Fund Classification: Existing equity funds need further classification to ensure alignment with the desired asset allocation, and some might be sector-specific or have a higher risk profile.
  • Indicative Rating Availability: Indicative ratings are not consistently available, limiting the ability to fully assess fund quality.
  • Concentration Risk: Relying solely on the PGIM fund family introduces concentration risk and diversification is key.

These risks highlight the importance of continuous monitoring, diversification, and professional financial advice to navigate market uncertainties and optimize investment outcomes. A financial advisor should be consulted for personalized financial guidance.
